summary: David Ferrie is an individual mentioned in several documents related to the JFK assassination investigation. The documents suggest Ferrie was involved in suspicious activities and conversations, as indicated by a phone call reported by Jimmy Johnson. He is connected to Lee Harvey Oswald through recollections of individuals like Anthony William Atzenhoffer Jr., who remembers them both being associated with the Civil Air Patrol Cadets (CAPC) in New Orleans. Phillip Geraci also recalls a limited association with Ferrie. One document mentions notes on Ferrie being forwarded from the CIA's Office of Legislative Counsel to the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). The timeline of his involvement spans from the time he was associated with Oswald in the CAPC to the period investigated by the HSCA.
significance: David Ferrie's significance in the JFK assassination context lies in his potential connections to Lee Harvey Oswald and his involvement in suspicious activities that drew the attention of investigators. His name appears in CIA documents and HSCA records, suggesting he was a person of interest in understanding the events surrounding the assassination.
